channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: A.N.C. Suffers Major Election Setback in South Africa
item.media:description: With a black party leader since last year, Mmusi Maimane, the Democratic Alliance appeared to have made inroads even in African National Congress strongholds.
item.description: For the African National Congress, it was the worst election since the party helped bring about the end of apartheid.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Ugandan Police Storm Gay Pride Event, Arresting at Least 15
item.description: Uganda's Police raided a night club where a Gay Pride event was underway and arrested at least 15 people, accusing them of staging an illegal gathering and promoting homosexuality.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Afghanistan Is in Chaos. Is That What Hamid Karzai Wants?
item.media:description: Hamid Karzai, the former president of Afghanistan, at his compound in Kabul last month.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Critics say the former president is working from the wings to destabilize his successor’s government. He says he has no interest in returning to power.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Syrians Seeking Asylum in South Korea Find Only a Cold Shoulder
item.media:description: Ahmad Barro, left, Ahmad al-Othman and Ahmad Khalifa last month in Yangju, South Korea. The men, all from Syria, expressed frustration as they talked about family members left in Aleppo.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: Wary of Muslim immigrants after attacks in Europe, South Korea lets 670 Syrians stay only on annual visas, limiting their ability to find jobs and barring them from benefits.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Kashmiri Faces Sedition Charges Over Facebook Activity
item.media:description: An Indian patrol on a street in Srinagar, Kashmir, on Tuesday.
item.description: Tauseef Ahmad Bhat, 29, was accused of “liking, sharing and posting anti-India content on Facebook,” a police official said.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Young Syrian Torchbearer Highlights Brazil’s Embrace of Refugees
item.media:description: Hanan Dacka with her mother, Yuba Bkri, and baby sister, Yara, in their apartment in São Paulo, Brazil.
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.description: An antipathy many feel toward the Games turned to cheers when Hanan Dacka, one of the 2,300 Syrian refugees Brazil has admitted, carried the Olympic flame in Brasília.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees

item.title: Olympic Spirit in Brazil? They Stoned the Torch Relay
item.media:description: Demonstrators along the route of the Olympic torch relay in Rio de Janeiro protested on Wednesday against the spending of government money on the Olympics instead of education.
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.description: With a president facing impeachment and a recession stunting the national economy, nearly two-thirds of Brazilians believe that hosting the Summer Games will have a negative effect on the country.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Colombia’s New, Legal Drug Barons Focus on Medical Marijuana
item.media:description: PharmaCielo’s greenhouses and operation in Ríonegro, Colombia.
item.media:credit: Jorge Panchoaga for The New York Times
item.description: Colombia revised a 30-year-old drug law and embraced medical marijuana; now private companies are betting that cannabis could be a market leader.
item.dc:creator: EZRA KAPLAN

item.title: What Price to Keep France Safe? Perhaps a Nation’s Core Values, Many Fear
item.media:description: French soldiers patrol the Promenade des Anglais on Thursday in Nice, France. Security along the French Riviera and across France has been stepped up following recent terrorist attacks.
item.description: As a presidential election approaches, extreme measures, rejected for now, might be harder to fend off as the country struggles with an internal security problem.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Syrian Girl Born Without an Eye Undergoes Surgery in Barcelona
item.description: Sham Aldaher will probably be able to leave the hospital by early next week, although more procedures will be required for her to receive a prosthetic, officials said.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Black Lives Matter Activists Stage Protests Across Britain
item.description: Members of the emerging movement in the country demonstrated in London, Birmingham, Nottingham and other cities, responding to calls for a nationwide protest against racial injustice.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Ahmed H. Zewail, Nobel-Prize-Winning Chemist, Dies at 70
item.media:description: Ahmed H. Zewail, left, in 1999 after being honored by President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt for winning the Nobel Prize.
item.description: Dr. Zewail, a naturalized American citizen, was the first Arab to win a Nobel in any of the sciences, and he championed science in Egypt and the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH CHANG
item.category: Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)

item.title: In Shift, Australia Pledges More Resources for Climate Research
item.media:description: The Cape Grim research station on the island of Tasmania plays a unique role in measuring greenhouse gases because of its location.
item.description: The measures do not completely reverse deep staff cuts to the country’s science agency that drew protests from scientists, but they appear to signal a turnaround.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (Australia)

item.title: 13 Killed in Separatist Attack in Northeastern India
item.media:description: Indian security personnel carried a wounded person from the site of the attack, in the northeastern state of Assam, on Friday.
item.description: It was the first major assault in nearly two years in a restive part of the state of Assam, where an ethnic group has been clamoring for autonomy.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: The Particle That Wasn’t
item.media:description: The Large Hadron Collider at CERN in 2014.
item.description: Physicists working at the Large Hadron Collider reveal that mounds of data did not support the possibility of a new particle.
item.dc:creator: DENNIS OVERBYE

item.title: Week of TV Trials in China Signals New Phase in Attack on Rights
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Zhou Shifeng, Gou Hongguo, Zhai Yanmin and Hu Shigen during their trials in Tianjin, China.
item.description: Legal experts and supporters denounced the hearings of four defendants, held on consecutive days in Tianjin, as grotesque show trials.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Sinosphere: Weighing the Strengths and Shortcomings of China’s Education System
item.media:description: High school seniors studying in preparation for the gaokao, the university entrance exam, in Lianyungang, China.
item.description: The economist Scott Rozelle, who wrote a study that challenges popular conceptions of Chinese education, explains why high schools are doing a better job than colleges.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Letter From Europe: Summer of Anxiety Eclipses the ‘Silly Season’ of Years Past
item.media:description: Police officers on patrol last month in Nice, France, after a truck plowed through crowds celebrating Bastille Day.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: Recent atrocities have challenged the theater of the absurd once peddled by newspapers amid the summer lull, making it more a spectacle of the macabre.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Debate Over Trump’s Fitness Raises Issue of Checks on Nuclear Power
item.media:description: The president’s emergency satchel — a black briefcase full of war plans, authentication codes, and communication devices follows him (or her) just about everywhere, carried by an aide trained in the procedures.
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: Brooks Kraft LLC/Corbis, via Getty; Stephen Crowley/The NYT; Diana Walker/Time & Life Pictures, via Getty; Bettmann Archive/Getty; Diana Walker/Time & Life Pictures, via Getty; J. Scott Applewhite/AP; Ron Edmonds/AP
item.description: There are no checks on a president’s power to wage nuclear war, though history suggests that there may be ways to slow down or derail the process.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM J. BROAD and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Lowell Goddard, Leader of Britain’s Child Sex Abuse Inquiry, Quits
item.media:description: Justice Lowell Goddard, the chairwoman of a British inquiry into the sexual abuse of children, in London last year.
item.description: The resignation followed news reports that the official had pay and benefits of at least $656,000 a year and spent 70 days of her first year working abroad or on vacation.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.category: Independent Inquiry Into Child Sexual Abuse

item.title: Fatah Makes Incendiary Facebook Claim of Killing 11,000 Israelis
item.media:description: The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, has repeatedly said he supports nonviolent resistance against the Israeli occupation.
item.description: The party, in an effort to appeal to Palestinians ahead of hotly contested elections, also claimed to have “offered 170,000 martyrs.”
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: What Is the #PalletsOfCash Debate?
item.media:description: Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch hinted ot CNN that American officials had discussed the optics of a $400 million cash delivery to Iran around the time of an American prisoner release.
item.media:credit: Edmund D. Fountain for The New York Times
item.description: The United States sent the first installment of $1.7 billion to Iran to settle a financial dispute at the same time Iran released American prisoners.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: $400 Million to Iran Was Not a Ransom, Obama Says
item.description: The president called the uproar over the payment, which was made public at the time as part of a landmark nuclear pact, “the manufacturing of outrage.”
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: Olympic Officials Set Russia’s Roster; More Than 100 Are Barred for Doping
item.media:description: Russian Olympians attend their welcome ceremony for the Rio 2016 Olympic Games at the Athletes Village on Wednesday.
item.description: But legal challenges remain likely, creating further confusion on the eve of the Rio Games.
item.dc:creator: REBECCA R. RUIZ

item.title: Pilot of Vanished Malaysian Flight Had Deviant Route on His Simulator, Minister Says
item.media:description: Relatives of passengers aboard Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 protested outside the Malaysian Embassy in Beijing on March 8, 2015, the one-year anniversary of the jetliner’s disappearance.
item.description: The Malaysian government acknowledged for the first time that the pilot of Flight 370, which is believed to have crashed in the southern Indian Ocean in 2014, had practiced such a route.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Turkey Issues a Warrant for Fethullah Gulen, Cleric Accused in Coup
item.media:description: A Turkish flag at Gundogdu Square in Izmir on Thursday during a rally to protest the failed coup attempt.
item.description: Mr. Gulen, who lives in a self-imposed exile in Pennsylvania, is accused of plotting the July 15 coup attempt that left more than 250 people dead.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: How a Suicide Bomber Made His Way From Syria to Strike in Ansbach, Germany
item.media:description: Police officers secured the area after the Ansbach explosion.
item.description: Mohammad Daleel, 27, wounded 15 people last month, three years after entering Europe illegally through Bulgaria. He received mental health therapy, and his full identity and motives remain unclear.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY and BORYANA DZHAMBAZOVA
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Scientific Evidence of Flood May Give Credence to Legend of China’s First Dynasty
item.media:description: A view of skeletons in a cave in a village called Lajia, which is said to have been destroyed in an earthquake in China thousands of years ago.
item.description: Historians have long wondered whether the Great Flood was a myth, but archaeologists and geologists have discovered data about a dam that supports the story.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS WADE

item.title: Boko Haram Leader Speaks on YouTube, Deepening Signs of Split
item.media:description: Abubakar Shekau in a video released by Boko Haram in 2014.
item.description: The audio recording of the leader, Abubakar Shekau, came hours after an Islamic State publication suggested that another militant had taken control of Boko Haram.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Trilobites: Finding Degas’s Lost Portrait With a Particle Accelerator
item.media:description: A portrait, seemingly of the model Emma Dobigny, that was painted over for another work by Edgar Degas. The image on the left was captured with conventional X-rays. The color reconstruction was made using data from X-ray fluorescence.
item.media:credit: Left: National Gallery of Victoria, Melbourne, Felton Bequest, 1937; Right: David Thurrowgood.
item.description: Australian researchers have used X-ray fluorescence to reconstruct a hidden portrait under one of Degas’s paintings in stunning resolution.
item.dc:creator: STEPH YIN

item.title: Wrenching Choice in South Sudan: Starve or Risk Rape
item.media:description: South Sudanese soldiers and displaced families at the Anglican church compound in Juba, the capital, last month.
item.description: Clashes between the country’s rival factions halted food distribution for tens of thousands of people in United Nations camps, and sexual violence has risen.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Government Forces Responsible for South Sudan Killings and Rapes, U.N. Official Says
item.media:description: South Sudanese women collected water in at a United Nations camp housing about 30,000 in Juba last month.
item.description: The United Nations human rights commissioner documented violence resulting from clashes between forces loyal to the president and to his rival, the vice president.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: The i360, World’s Most ‘Slender’ Tower, Opens in England
item.media:description: The British Airways i360 observation tower in Brighton, England, on Tuesday.
item.description: As with many ambitious architectural projects, opinions of the futuristic 531-foot-high structure in Brighton are divided.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Bangladeshi Police Arrest 2 Suspected of Terror Attack on Bakery
item.media:description: Bangladeshi police officers at a checkpoint on a road leading to the Holey Artisan Bakery, the scene of a fatal attack and siege last month, in Dhaka, the capital.
item.description: Tahmid Khan, a student at the University of Toronto, and Hasnat Karim, a Briton working in Bangladesh, were said to have been hostages during the attack last month.
item.dc:creator: MAHER SATTAR and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Thailand Junta Seeks to Extend Its Power With Constitutional Referendum
item.media:description: Gen. Prayuth Chan-ocha, the prime minister and chief of the junta, in the southern Thai province of Narathiwat last month. The military government has blocked opponents from campaigning against a referendum on a new constitution.
item.description: The ruling generals have cast the national vote as essential to restoring democracy, but critics say the proposal would weaken the role of elected officials.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.category: National Council for Peace and Order (Thailand)
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Rome Journal: Roma Women’s Business Plan: Cook Their Way to a Better Life
item.media:description: Maria Miclescu, left, and Codruca Balteanu at a food stand run by the Gipsy Queens during a music festival in Rome in July.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: Eager to build a future for their families outside Rome’s segregated camps, a group called the Gipsy Queens began a cooking business.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Israel Charges Aid Group’s Gaza Branch Manager With Funneling Funds to Hamas
item.media:description: Mohammad El Halabi — an employee of World Vision, a Christian aid organization — at his indictment on Thursday on charges of funneling about $43 million in charity funds to Hamas.
item.description: Mohammad El Halabi, of World Vision’s Gaza branch, was said to have moved about $43 million over the past six years to the militant group’s military wing.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and DIAA HADID

item.title: Zhou Shifeng, Chinese Lawyer, Is Sentenced to 7 Years for Subversion
item.media:description: The lawyer Zhou Shifeng at his trial in Tianjin, China, on Thursday, in an image taken from video. His firm, Fengrui, represented dissidents like the artist Ai Weiwei and victims of a contaminated baby formula scandal in 2008.
item.description: Mr. Zhou was the focus of government ire as the leader of a law firm with nearly 100 employees, many of whom specialized in cases officials deemed sensitive.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Man Held After London Knife Attack That Killed an American
item.media:description: The police investigating the scene of a knife attack at Russell Square in London, near the British Museum.
item.description: The police said “mental health issues” appeared to have led to the attack in Russell Square, which also left five people wounded.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s Straddling Bus, on a Test Run, Floats Above the Streets
item.media:description: A prototype of the Transit Elevated Bus, which is 72 feet long and 26 feet wide, going for a test run in the Chinese seaside city of Qinhuangdao on Tuesday.
item.description: A colossal, street-straddling bus came a step closer to reality this week, when a prototype went for a trial run of a few hundred yards.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and EMILY FENG

item.title: Sinosphere: China Reins In Communist Youth League, and Its Alumni’s Prospects
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping in Beijing last month. The Communist Party has announced a major reorganization of its Youth League, a training ground for many officials who have been marginalized under Mr. Xi.
item.description: The league has served as a cradle for generations of Chinese leaders, who rose through it into the high ranks of the party.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: What in the World: The Face of Taiwan’s Past Is Slowly Fading From View
item.media:description: More than 200 statues of Chiang Kai-shek, the Chinese Nationalist leader who died in 1975, have been moved to a park near his mausoleum in Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan.
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.description: As the island has democratized, statues and busts of Chiang Kai-shek, the longtime president of the Republic of China, are gradually being either removed or relocated.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: What in the World: British Royal History, and Intrigue, in a Quaint German Town
item.media:description: The German town of Celle is an ancestral home of Britain’s royal family, the Windsors.
item.description: Celle, Germany, has played host to British royals on several occasions because of its role as an ancestral home of the House of Windsor.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: What in the World: A Mother’s Love? Of Course. Her Citizenship? Not So Fast.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; Photo by Glyphstock/shutterstock
item.description: Laws in 27 countries say that only fathers, not mothers, confer their nationality on a child. If Dad is dead or missing, Baby may wind up stateless.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Opinion: Trump, the Bad, Bad Businessman
item.media:description: Taking down the sign for the Trump Plaza Casino in Atlantic City in 2014, when it closed.
item.description: The real estate and casino developer I covered as a reporter in the 1990s was a disaster.
item.dc:creator: NEIL BARSKY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: For Putin, Disinformation Is Power
item.media:description: A Russian police officer during a rally in support of Vladimir V. Putin in Moscow in 2012.
item.description: When Americans gloated about winning the Cold War, they opened a door for Russians’ resentment — and Putin’s tactics.
item.dc:creator: ARKADY OSTROVSKY

item.title: Editorial: Stuck in Platitudes on Migration Crisis
item.media:description: Syrian refugees near the village of Idomeni, Greece.
item.description: Addressing the global exodus of refugees and migrants will require concrete, binding commitments.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Outstanding Issues: A Yemeni Teenager’s Trip to Estonia, by Way of Guantánamo
item.media:description: Ahmed Abdul Qader, a former Guantánamo Bay detainee, at Freedom Square in Tallinn, Estonia, in May.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The reporter Charlie Savage wrote about an ex-Guantánamo inmate’s resettlement; the story didn’t end when the article published.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Voices From Europe’s Far Right
item.media:description: “Our economy doesn’t increase along with the never-ending supply of immigrants,” wrote Mikael Jakobsen, 24, a law student in Aarhus, Denmark.
item.media:credit: Michael Drost-Hansen for The New York Times
item.description: Hundreds of readers from across the Continent responded to our call to share their experiences as supporters of far-right parties.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
